ygData.subject: Re: Is environmental information helpful for developmental complexity?
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, thanks for raising this interesting question.  There are a few ways to look at this issue. One option is to take a hard-line perspective to see how far

Jeff, thanks for raising this interesting question.  There are a few ways=
 to look at this issue.  

One option is to take a hard-line perspective to=
 see how far the most extreme form of CPPN-alone argument can go.  It would=
 go something like:  We can just look at the environment in this case as an=
other geometric coordinate cue in lieu of something better.  That is, the a=
ir hitting these cells is just a way of telling them they are in that part =
of the lung.  If you look at it that way, it might not be so profound.  Tha=
t is, a coordinate would have been just as good for communicating such info=
rmation as an arbitrary environmental cue.  And this kind of environment-ba=
sed trick hardly addresses the global probably of cells needing to know whe=
re they are.

On the other hand, it's probably more reasonable to acknowled=
ge a useful role for the environment in some aspects of development.  In th=
is case, it may well be that oxygen coming in is a good heuristic for knowi=
ng what kind of cell you should be.  So the environment was put to good use=
.  Yet if you look at the overall construction of the body, it appears over=
all there is only so much the environment can tell you (internally), so it =
shouldn't be overstated.

Yet the one place where there is evidently a ton =
of environmental influence is the brain.  Learning or adaptation is a form =
of environmentally-mediated development.  All the signals that come in thro=
ugh the sensors ultimately shape the connectivity of the brain, so the envi=
ronment is playing a strong role in the development of adaptive neural netw=
orks.  Certainly we will need to ultimately capture that capability to evol=
ve realistic brains.

Yet I believe such functionality can complement and e=
xtend CPPNs without replacing their central role in encoding neural structu=
res.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
=
> Hello all-
> 
> The article below is interesting. It suggests that lung c=
ells know to become
> lung cells based on the air passing back and forth ov=
er them. It is
> intriguing in the context of HyperNEAT because it shows th=
at sometimes
> nature does not use geometric position (provided by complex =
protein
> patterning) to make differentiation decisions, but uses environme=
ntal cues.
> Of course, HyperNEAT could create the same end product just wi=
th positional
> information, but it might be easier to accomplish this with=
 simple
> environmental-based tricks like this one. Thoughts?
> 
> New Scie=
ntist
> Breath of fresh air transforms stem cells
> 
> 14:32 09 November 20=
09 by Andy Coghlan
> For similar stories, visit the Stem Cells Topic Guide
=
> Mimicking the environment experienced by cells in the windpipe is enough =
to
> transform stem cells into a range of different lung cells. Such "physi=
cal"
> techniques could be used to create specialised tissues when growth f=
actors
> alone aren't enough.
> 
> Lindsey Van Haute of the Free University=
 of Brussels (VUB) in Belgium and
> colleagues spread human embryonic stem =
cells onto a porous membrane. The
> cells were fed from beneath by nutrient=
s and from above by a fluid that
> encouraged them to multiply. Removing tw=
o chemicals from the growth fluid
> kickstarted differentiation.
> 
> Four =
days later, the team removed the fluid covering the cells, leaving them
> o=
pen to the air while still being sustained and supported from below, as
> t=
hey would be in the trachea. After 24 days the cells had developed surface
=
> proteins that identified them as specific types of lung cell, including
>=
 alveolar cells, which allow the exchange of gases, and cilia, which expel
=
> bacteria and dirt.
> 
> Physical influence
> 
> "Our study proves differe=
ntiation into lung cells is influenced by physical
> forces," says Van Haut=
e. Previously, stem cells have been made to
> differentiate into lung cells=
 using a cocktail of different growth factors,
> but Haute says using physi=
cal forces might be simpler.
> 
> "Physical forces are certainly a factor i=
n getting the lung lining to be
> fully functional," says Anne Bishop at Im=
perial College London, who has made
> alveolar cells from mouse stem cells =
using growth factors alone. "But I find
> it difficult to believe that raw =
stem cells would differentiate through to
> these uncommon types of cells s=
olely in response to physical forces."
> 
> Haute's team plans to use the c=
ells they created to study lung diseases,
> such as cystic fibrosis. Such c=
ells might one day be used to treat people
> with damaged lung tissue, but =
only if the cells can be made from a person's
> own tissue. This could be d=
one by converting the cells first into induced
> pluripotent stem cells.
> =

> Journal reference: Respiratory Research, DOI: 10.1186/1465-9921-10-105
>=
 
> 
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
